title: Monday, 7th March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

Minded to share a book cover as today's image

PM

But don't take this as an inducement to go and buy the book

11:01 am
PM

PM

Here's a bit of a review in the New Scientist

PM

Introducing The Persuaders, philosopher James Garvey describes the event that motivated him to write the book: a panic that seized him after he had bested a public speaker with a killer objection – and it had made no difference. The speaker had stuck to his views. What price argument and reason? Garvey writes that the idea life turns largely on stuff other than reason “menaces me more than a little”.

11:02 am
PM

So what does run the show? After centuries of the ancient Greeks worshipping reason and evidence, after the debating clubs at the peak of the Enlightenment, we are now a world filled with conspiracy theories and optional realities. The rules have changed. Reason and argument are dead. And Garvey, who works at the Royal Institute of Philosophy, thinks he knows what killed them: public relations.

Over the past century, the PR industry has increasingly studied our psychology and identified the chinks in our mental armour. For example, Garvey cites the social psychology of pioneering neurosurgeon Wilfred Trotter, who found that our opinions are shaped not by reason and logic but by our in-group allegiances.

Seizing on such insights, and everything else that came their way, the PR industry designed tools to override critical reasoning: emotional appeals, status anxiety and so on.

It started with simple advertising but soon, realising the extraordinary potential, the PR industry colonised every arena of modern life, from politics to science communication, until there was no more room for reasoned debate. These days everyone has a PR company doing their wicked work, warping our realities to suit their agendas.

PM

Basically blaming feltcollaredsource for everything that's wrong in modern life

PM

Fact that many people have abandoned logic can be blamed on too much PR

PM

National People's Congress underway over there

11:07 am
BE

PM

Let me get some Cap Economics

PM

Official statements at the National People’s Congress have signalled, as expected, that the immediate
economic priority is to support growth including with a looser fiscal stance and more monetary
support. This should help drive a cyclical recovery, even if actual growth falls short of the
government’s lofty target.
 The annual meeting of the National People’s Congress (NPC), China’s parliament, began in Beijing on
Saturday. It will continue into next week, but many of the key events, including the premier’s work
report and the budget report, were scheduled for the first day.
 The government has set a target range for growth in 2016 of “6.5% to 7.0%”, as had been expected.
This move to a range-based target has been interpreted by some as a sign of greater flexibility. But the
practical difference relative to last year’s target of “about 7.0%” is small. Moreover, the government has
reiterated its commitment to achieving average growth of at least 6.5% over the next five years, which
leaves little room to reduce the target in future and underlines its reluctance to abandon numeric goals.
 The economy will almost certainly not grow at anything close to these rates. Few now believe the
official GDP figures and recent polls suggest that most analysts estimate that growth has in reality
already fallen well below the government’s 6.5% bottom line. (An anonymous Consensus Economics
poll last month put growth in 2015 at 4.3%, about the same as shown by our China Activity Proxy.) The
government’s continued insistence on unrealistically-high targets only serves to put pressure on the
statistics bureau to overstate the pace at which the economy is growing.
 The government has defended its lofty growth targets by claiming they are necessary “to ensure
employment”. But with the economy increasingly driven by labour-intensive services, a much lower
level of growth would be more than sufficient to ensure a healthy labour market. Indeed, even with
growth in all likelihood falling well short of the target last year, China added 13 million net new urban
jobs, surpassing the government’s target of 10 million. That target has been left unchanged for 2016.

11:08 am
PM

Putting our scepticism over the growth target aside, the NPC does provide some reasons to be
relatively upbeat about the near-term outlook. First, the budget report points to a looser fiscal stance.
The Ministry of Finance has raised the official budget deficit from 2.3% of GDP for 2015 to 3.0% for this
year. The actual deficit is likely to be larger. Recent efforts to bring off-budget government spending onto
the budget have made the official budget balance more relevant as a guide to the fiscal stance. But it still
omits some spending via government-managed funds and local government financing vehicles. Adding
these in and adjusting for shifts in the budget stabilisation fund, this year’s budget implies an
“augmented” fiscal deficit of around 4.5%, up from 3.9% last year.

Loved this correction in Saturday's Guardian..

11:11 am
PM

• A review of David Astor: A Life in Print, a biography of the former editor of the Observer, contained a number of errors (20 February, page 7, Review). In the article we suggested that William Waldorf Astor was named after a hotel, when in fact his name referred to the family’s native Rhineland village. He didn’t build Cliveden, as we suggested, but bought it, and he didn’t sack the editor of the Observer for spiking his contributions (although he did sack the editor of the Pall Mall Gazette, another Astor acquisition, for spiking his contributions). We said Katharine Whitehorn was women’s editor of the Observer when in fact she was a columnist. We said Patrick Leigh Fermor compared David Astor to Disney’s Pluto; Fermor actually compared the writer Philip Toynbee to that cartoon character. Terence Kilmartin replaced Jim Rose as Observer literary editor, not JC Trewin. During the war, David Astor didn’t merely suffer “a mild attack of dysentery” as suggested in the review. In fact he was wounded in action during a German ambush in the Ardennes. Terence Kilmartin is believed to have been involved in his rescue, and Astor was awarded the Croix de Guerre.

PM

We've all been there.

PM

I once got the Guardian's year end figures wrong

BE

Okay, after the twelve minute preamble, let's do some platitudes.

11:13 am
BE

Everything that went up last week is down this week.

BE

Volume's a bit low but it's a Monday so that's expected.

BE

Anglo, having more than doubled, is down a tad.

11:13 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 564.10, down 27.9 (-4.71%), High: 622.40, Low: 561.70, Volume: 7.38m
BE

Helped by a UBS downgrade, which you're welcome to.

BE

We downgrade Anglo to Sell (from Neutral), lifting our price target to £4.00/s. The
stock is up 137% from the low in mid-Jan, outperforming the sector by ~85%. We
believe the outlook for Anglo's key commodity prices has not improved materially and
the execution risk with the proposed restructuring remains high. Our key concern is
that Anglo will struggle to sell coal, nickel and iron ore assets at attractive prices in the
current market and thus, if they do, it could be destructive to shareholder value.

11:15 am
PM

Prefers Glencore instead

BE

There's a bit more to it than "it's gone up a lot," though that's the gist.

BE

In this note we ask and answer what we see as the three pivotal questions for Anglo
currently: Can Anglo raise US$7bn from disposals? Is the recent uptick in diamonds and
platinum prices sustainable? Does Anglo need additional capital over the next 2yrs if
prices return from lows? We believe Anglo will struggle to raise US$7bn from disposals,
though the near-term target of US$3-4bn by end-FY16 is possible. We believe the
fundamentals for platinum and diamonds remain challenging and a material recovery in
prices near-term is unlikely. Platinum still lacks supply discipline and is being pulled up
by gold, while we expect diamonds to be held back by high rough inventories and
growing supply. We believe Anglo's balance sheet is well structured, but vulnerable
from FY18 if commodity prices are lower for longer.

11:15 am
BE

We update forecasts following FY15 results to reflect the new guidance and weaker
R/US$; we lift FY16 EBITDA by 10% (lower costs at Kumba, stronger sales at De Beers,
and lower Coal costs) with FY17/18 broadly unchanged. We see 2 incremental positives
from the results: 1) FCF positive in FY16: management now expects Anglo to generate
~US$0.4bn of FCF in FY16 (up from US$1bn outflow expected in Dec-15), mainly due
to incremental savings (+US$0.8bn) and FX. 2) Disposals: Anglo has already engaged
buyers for 5 assets (including Niobium/Phosphates, Nickel, Moranbah & Grosvenor) and
preliminary interest is good.

BE

We lift our target to £4.00/s (from £2.90/s), with our target NPV multiple lifted to 0.4x
(from 0.3x) to reflect improved FCF generation and divestment progress. However, we
cut our rating to Sell (from Neutral) as we see a high restructuring execution risk and a
balance sheet that is vulnerable in a lower-for-longer price environment.

BE

In terms of S32, that's a UBS upgrade.

11:16 am
BE

Up 4.9% at 75p as I type.

BE

Two of the main commodity exposures of South32 (4 of its 10 assets), Manganese (Mn)
and Alumina (Al2O3) were sold off in late 2015. Mn prices declined to a low of
US$1.74/dmtu (Tianjin), while alumina prices fell to a low of US$198.06/t in mid Jan
16. At that time, the spot price was trading between the 75th and 80th percentile of
the cost curves, implying 75-80% of global production was losing cash (including S32).
As a result, the supply side has reacted, with ~12Mt and 7Mt of production (~11% and
~18% of global supply) closed respectively out of the Al2O3 and Mn markets. Alumina
prices have rebounded 22% and manganese 58%, while South32 has also announced
a manganese business restructure and targeted cost out across its operations.

BE

Incorporating the 1H FY 16 result, as well as revised cost/capex guidance has raised our
S32 earnings forecasts by 180%, 67% and 30% respectively in FY 16/17/18. This has
been primarily driven by cost and capex improvements at Worsley, Illawarra and Cerro
Matoso. These changes have also increased our NPV by 23% to A$2.07ps. S32's FCF
yield is 6.8% (6.7% @ spot) in FY 16, cf RIO & BHP at 3.2% and 2.1%. S32's FY 16
EV/EBITDA adj of 4.2x compares favourably to RIO (CY) & BHP at 8.3x & 9.1x,
respectively. In FY 17e, with higher commodity prices and also lower costs and capex,
FCF yield lifts to 15.6% and is still respectable at spot FX & pricing at 9.6%.

11:16 am
BE

We upgrade to Buy rating (prev. Neutral) to reflect improving cash flow and attractive
metrics. Our price target lifts to A$1.70ps (prev. A$1.45ps), set at 0.8x NPV (unch).

BE

As for Lonmin and Kenmare ..... debt means they're still binary, so it's very difficult to extrapolate an awful lot from daily volatility.

"Our ability to increase and manage choice for consumers, while supporting restaurants with technology and marketing that creates value, resulted in continued strong global growth in our business in 2015. Revenues were up 58% to £247.6 million, with Underlying EBITDA up 83% to £59.7 million. We are now market-leader in 12 out of 13 territories. Our business is becoming increasingly global, with our international business now larger and growing even quicker than our UK business was at the time of IPO.

These results prove the strength of our model, validate our value-enhancing approach to M&A and provide an excellent platform for continued expansion in 2016.

BE

PM

Current Trading and Outlook
Strong trading momentum has continued into 2016. Investment for growth in areas such as technology, marketing and people will continue and, as a result, the Board expects 2016 revenues of £350 million and Underlying EBITDA of between £98-100 million at current exchange rates."

11:21 am
BE

BE

BE

David Reynolds at Jefferies just sounds exasperated.

11:22 am
BE

Today is a day for the bears, following the share sales. We understand that they are rarely positive, but for a stock that has been travelling a rollercoaster of sentiment in recent weeks, we felt it useful perhaps to share some perspective. We think Buttress and Wroe have performed very well leading Just Eat as a public company. Where it matters, in the numbers, an exemplary track record. Neither are founders nor excessively compensated, in our view.

BE

We get it..... Senior management share sales rarely a positive.

BE

2016 has been extraordinarily sentiment driven. While we don't claim to understand the 'market', 2016 has delivered material swings in the JE equity price, largely driven by sentiment around all things GrubHub and last mile delivery and indeed the valuation disparity between GRUB and JE, perceptions of a changing competitive dynamic in the UK, the rise and rise of Deliverwho and the customary repeated references to Amazon and Uber. Latterly the almost manic focus in JE's FY15 results on Denmark....very curious....

11:22 am
BE

The share sales will be criticised.... Particularly around the timing and sentiment.
In search of perspective... Perhaps three points to make;
Senior Management teams cannot control market sentiment, arguably, nor should they try...and personally we think it may be better simply to ignore it;
In terms of share sales, the aspiration should be 'to establish a clear pattern...', in JE's case, limited track record as a public company, but the pattern seems to be - straight after the full year print; and
Neither are founders, neither appear particularly excessively paid. This is clearly a 'cash in' trade, taking both close to the 400% salary requirement.

BE

...and as a reminder, we get it..... Senior management share sales rarely a positive.

BE

How have Buttress and Wroe performed? JE came public April 2014 at 260p;
In terms of the maiden year, FY14, JE communicated on four occasions, all positive, ahead of expectations and delivering on IPO guidance;
FY15, communicated on five occasions, all undeniably positive, established formal guidance at the revenue line, 'marginally exceed £200m' on 17 March. Lifted that twice, finally on 3 November, 'revenue slightly ahead £240m, EBITDA in line'. Printed £247.6m, +58% YoY and adjusted EBITDA £59.7m, a 24.1% margin and c. 9% ahead consensus.
On 1 March 2016, set the FY16 guide, and for the first time, revenue and EBITDA, revenue £350m, +41% YoY growth, adjusted EBITDA £98m to £100m, at the mid-point, a 28.3% margin, +420 bps YoY.
Or put another way... Sentiment is sentiment; at the end of the day, it's about the numbers. Buttress and Wroe have delivered, better than expectation, pretty much on every single occasion on which they communicated. It seems they have not been anything other than strategically focused, operationally excellent and financially diligent. And in a high growth business, riding the wave of digital disruption...those qualities are not that common.

11:23 am
BE

...but we do get it..... Senior management share sales rarely a positive.

BE

"Rarely" should really read "never", I'd have thought.

PM

So is he a buyer or seller now?

11:23 am
BE

PM

So he reckons these guys are great managers, but rubbish investors

BE

Yup, and the whole tone is somewhat wounded. That note reads a bit like a parent who's been called into the office because their kid's set fire to the bike sheds.

11:25 am
BE

Caz approaches things slightly differently.

BE

It was announced on Friday 4 March that management had sold shares,
including both JSOP shares and some directly held: While the share sales
read negatively, we think the details are much less negative. Parts of the shares
sold are awards under a pre-IPO scheme (JSOP), amounting to 1.475m and
0.93m of the shares sold by the CEO and CFO. Under the scheme, the
management were provided loans by the company to pay for the participation
cost. When these shares vest, the management needs to repay the loans, pay the
vesting price and potentially pay tax, and therefore pay a substantial amount out
of pocket. This is also against a backdrop of the CEO and CFO base salaries
having only recently being brought more into line with other similar FTSE250
companies. We note that last year the management similarly sold their JSOP
shares that vested.

BE

 Directly held shares sold amounted to 1.72m and 0.76m by the CEO and
CFO: Management have relatively short windows within which to sell shares
and we think the sale of additional direct shares reflects pent-up sales for this
year and last year (with last year being relatively too close to the time of IPO).
We think the sales are for personal purposes and are not a reflection on the
potential performance of the company or belief in the company’s recently
issued guidance (which as a reminder was 6%/8% above 2016 company
consensus at the revenue/EBITDA level). Although the CEO and CFO now hold
0.5m and 0.35m shares directly: 1) they are still to be awarded a further 1.46m
and 1.00m under the JSOP, and 2) moreover, are likely to receive substantial
additional shares under the company’s long-term incentive plan as a public
company.

11:25 am
BE

"reflects pent-up sales for this year and last year ..........."

BE

BUT THEY SOLD SEVERAL MILLION IN APRIL!

11:27 am

BE

11:27 am
BE

 We are Overweight the stock: We are OW, and see upside potential to our
base case assumptions, which offer 2015-18E CAGRs of 31% for revenue and
54% for EBITDA, together with high cash conversion. We see further potential
upside to numbers from better-than-expected order volumes (as H1 15, Q3 15
results and FY 15 order volumes have all demonstrated), additional M&A, the
Brazilian JV, move into pick-up/collection, and faster-than-expected increases in
commission rates (we currently model the next increase only in 2017 in the UK).
On our estimates, the stock trades on 16/17 EV/EBITDA of 25x/15x, a
3.1%/5.3% Eq FCF yield and a 3-yr PEG of 1.1.

BE

Anyway, they sell. Follow their lead. sell

Quick stopover at our old favourite

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 255.10, down 13.2 (-4.92%), High: 270.40, Low: 253.70, Volume: 795.81k
11:29 am
BE

11:29 am
BE

BE

BE

Prime Now is currently only available in certain postcodes e.g. in London, Birmingham and Liverpool. We had a choice of greater than 5k SKUs, c.2x the range of a discounter and ¼ the range of a supermarket, although with very limited fresh and chilled product, which typically accounts for 40% of grocery sales.

11:30 am
BE

Based on a small sample of 30 products, our price comparison shows Amazon Prime Now to be c.20% below Asda and c.25% below Ocado. Amazon Prime members get delivery within 1 hour for £6.99 or within a 2 hour, same-day window for free, from 8am to midnight. Based on an avg. delivery fee for the market of £2.50, a customer could get the 1 hour delivery and would still be broadly neutral on the combined product and delivery fee, for a basket of c.£30, and make a net saving on a basket over £30. We expect this business is loss-making for Amazon.

BE

Now, there are some oddities in their basket that, at first glance, seem to distort the totals a bit.

BE

Like a kilo of chocolate biscuits

11:30 am
BE

And a kilo of cheddar.

BE

BE

Here's UBS

BE

In our detailed note on the Wealth Management operations (available here) we valued
these businesses at c£4.6bn as at FY16E and concluded that the businesses are
strategically better placed than peers to take advantage of the changing U.K.
Retirement industry landscape. While we expected a spin-off (via IPO) of this business
only after the completion of its administration system migration (expected Q1 17), we
believe a cash sale for the businesses could accelerate this process. Allowing for this
valuation and the market value of listed subsidiaries, the remaining emerging markets
operation is valued at an implied 0.65xEV(FY15E), a deep discount to peers (0.8-1.1x).

11:40 am
BE

Our investment thesis for Old Mutual includes the further simplification of the group's
structure, which this break-up would achieve. Our SOTP based price target includes a
10% conglomerate discount on all parts of the business (excl debt) as a result of the
current group structure. We argue that in the event of a split of the group this discount
could be reduced, if not eliminated and therefore potentially unlock an additional
c14% upside (c24p/sh) over and above our current price target for the stock.

BE

And Bernstein, or edited highlights thereof.

BE

We think a break-up makes plenty of sense. Although Old Mutual, under its former CEO, did much to clean-up and simplify its portfolio, the Group remains a disparate collection of businesses which generates the majority of its earnings (68%) in rand. Moreover, Old Mutual stands at a significant disadvantage to peers under Solvency II as exchange controls mean that it is not permitted to recognise surplus South African capital in its Group Solvency position. This means that its headline Group Solvency II ratio, when announced at the FY results, is likely to be much lower than that of peers.

11:42 am
BE

We think a sale of OMW would result in the Group relocating its headquarters to South Africa, and lending greater focus to growing its African businesses, which makes plenty of strategic sense. We think OMW could be worth 20x FY16 earnings and that the Group could reduce corporate centre costs and intangibles by 73%. Taken together, this would add 11% to our Target Price, implying 17% upside to Friday's close. Whilst we expect the stock to trade up today on this speculation, there isn't quite enough upside at the moment to make us a buyer of the stock. However, if the CEO were also to announce a compelling strategic plan for bringing the African businesses closer together, then the investment case could get more interesting

BE

Bernstein puts wealth at £4.5bn, or half Old Mut's market cap.

Gate Ventures Plc has led a 'Series A' bridging round for Ensygnia, the leading provider of secure and frictionless mobile payment solutions, in which it made a strategic investment of £500,000 for an 8.54% stake.

Other significant investors in the funding round include prominent US FinTech Accelerator and venture fund, SixThirty. SixThirty's founder Jim McKelvey, is also a co-founder of Square, the NYSE (New York Stock Exchange) quoted electronic payment services company.

11:44 am

In fact, twice before we observed and commented on
a similar type of market reaction (see our note October opportunity in
November, dated 6 November 2015), and both times the market eventually
reverted to fundamentals relatively quickly.

BE

In Figure 1 we present the average (not market weighted) YtD performance of
the main UK oil and gas names (TLW, CNE, NOG, OPHR, PMO, SIA)
compared to the performance to the near-month Brent contract and the Dec
2020 contract. This time we’ve excluded Genel (GENL LN, 89.03p, Hold)
where poor performance was largely due to its own mishaps rather than
market momentum.

11:54 am
BE

Here's Fig 1.

BE

BE

From the chart, it is clear that in the last week the UK mid-cap O&G names are
once again reacting to the near-term move in the oil price, while the long-term
oil price stays virtually flat. This in our view creates an interesting phenomena:
fundamentally the O&G equities are priced on a long-term oil price
assumption, however momentum wise (i.e. daily volatility) they seem to
trade following the near term contract. In a stable oil-price environment this
is typically not a problem as the near-term and the long-term oil price move in
conjunction. However, in a volatile oil price environment the divergence
between the two oil prices often creates short-term opportunities in the
equities, in our view.

11:55 am
BE

To further emphasize our point, in Figure 2 we show what we estimate these
equities (on NAV basis) are now pricing in terms of post 2016 long-term oil
price (assuming $40/bbl in 2016). On average these equities are pricing in a
$65/bbl, significantly higher than the current forward curve. Additionally,
excluding GENL and NOGN, the remaining five are pricing in our view an
unrealistic level of $72/bbl.

BE

We do not believe this situation is sustainable and something has to give:
either the shares of these companies will pull back (which was the case last
time this opportunity presented) or the long-end of the curve will have to adjust
upwards. Therefore we propose the following trade: overweight the Dec2020
contract and underweight a synthetic index of the following companies:
TLW (TLW LN, 207p, Sell), Ophir (OPHR LN, 82.5p, Sell,), Cairn (CNE LN,
173,7p, Sell), Premier (PMO LN, 41.85p, Sell) and Soco (SIA LN, 170p, Sell).
Note that we have excluded Nostrum (NOGN LN, 267.1p, Buy) from the
synthetic index as we think it makes the recommendation even more
compelling (Figure 3). (pricing is intraday, 4 March 2016)

Fastjet has warned that challenging trading conditions have continued for longer than expected. Management expects 2016E earnings to be materially below current expectations, and we have cut our estimates accordingly. Liberum
UK | TRANSPORT & LEISURE | FJET LN | MARKET CAP £45m | 7 March 2016

Fastjet
2016E and 2017E forecasts cut on challenging conditions
Under Review (from Buy)
Target price Under Review | Published price 67.25p

Fastjet has warned that challenging trading conditions have continued for longer than expected. Management expects 2016E earnings to be materially below current expectations, and we have cut our estimates accordingly. Cost cuts are being implemented and the route network and capacity realigned to match current demand. Our revised forecasts show the group having sufficient cash to see it through to profitability. However, the trading environment remains uncertain and the company has flagged that it may consider a fundraising to provide additional headroom. We place our recommendation and target price under review (previously Buy, TP 90p).

Challenging trading conditions have continued

The challenging trading conditions affecting much of the African aviation industry have continued. In particular, we believe that economic activity in Tanzania has stagnated for longer than expected following the election late last year. Tanzania is Fastjet’s largest market and where the majority of its fleet is deployed.

We believe that activity is now starting to recover, but it is clear that the group is unlikely to match our previous expectations. We suspect that Fastjet’s rapid growth rate has added to the challenging market conditions. For example, the rapid launch of flights between Tanzania and Nairobi following Kenyan government clearance was important to head off any legal challenge from competitors, but the limited advance marketing has hurt the early performance of these routes, especially since this took place in the seasonally weakest period of the year.

12:02 pm
PM

Growth plans scaled back, costs cut

Management is taking action to offset the weaker financial performance. Operating costs are being cut, with cuts to head office overheads already being implemented. We understand that management is investigating other opportunities for cost savings, with supplier contracts likely to be a focus.

We expect fleet growth to pause this year, although capacity growth will remain strong reflecting the full year effect of the additional aircraft introduced into service at the end of 2015.

We believe fleet growth should resume next year, subject to economic conditions, although the number of additional aircraft will also depend on regulatory approvals for new bases. Zambia remains on the to-do list, although it is unlikely to be an immediate priority. We would expect an air operator's certificate to be secured later this year, although 2017 seems a more likely launch date for operations based in that country.
